oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Braden-Sinai School: right angle view of french doors
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Color photograph of the front, east facade of the building. It features five sets of French doors doors with two transoms over each. The French doors were originally tall double-hung windows. Two chimneys protrude from the red, tin, side gable roof. The building is characterized by clapboard siding. A later addition is visible on the far north end. It features an extension of the red, tin, side gable roof supported by wooden arches.

The Braden-Sinai School was built circa 1920 with possible support from the Julius Rosenwald Fund. It was used as for a Head Start Program and then remained vacant for 18 years. By 1995, it became a residential home and the tall, double-hung windows were replaced with French doors.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Julius Rosenwald Fund -- Buildings; African American schools -- Tennessee; Buildings--Remodeling for other use
